section.title: Strongly connected components
section.para: GINsim allows to compute the graph of the Strongly Connected Components (SCC graph, cf. ) of an existing graph, through the SCC graph option of the Actions menu. The SCC graph is an acyclic graph abstracted from the original one: each node of the SCC graph corresponds to a cycle or a set of intertwined cycles of the original graph. The resulting graph is thus usually much more compact.

caption.simpara: Example of Strongly Connected Component Graph (bottom right) and the corresponding statetransition graph (top left). The Selection Attribute tab in the bottom panel shows the content of the selected SCC (i.e. the list of nodes in the original graph).

section.para: Note that the SCC Graph tool can also be applied to regulatory graphs.

section.title: Path finder
section.para: The "search path" action enables the determination of paths between pairs of states of the state transition graph. Selecting the "search a path" action in the action menu opens a configuration dialog box, which allows the specification of a starting state, a target state , and optional intermediate states (using the "+" and "X" buttons to add/remove them). GINsim then performs a shortest path search. If several paths exist between these states, the first encountered shortest path is returned.

section.title: Animation plugin
section.para: The animation tool is launched through the Animate option of the Action menu of a state transition graph. It allows to interactively follow a trajectory in the state transition graph. Genes of the regulatory graph are highlighted, to display the corresponding activity levels (cf. ).

To follow a trajectory in the state transition graph, select a starting state. It is then colorized in blue and added to the trajectory (listed in the animation dialog box). Its successor states are highlited, and can be added to the trajectory upon selection, which in turns changes the available successor states.
To build another trajectory, select a state in the dialog and press the "<<" button to remove it and all of its successors.
To view the defined trajectory, select the starting state and press the "|>" button.

section.title: Trajectory visualisation with gnuplot
section.para: A path created with the animation plugin or found by the path finder can be visualized using gnuplot. The "GP" button (in the path finder and in the animator box) opens the gnuplot export box ().

mediaobject.caption: The gnuplot export box enables the selection of the kind of graph to create as well as the genes to display.

section.para: After selecting the kind of output and the genes to display, click "export" and choose a place to save the plot. Note that two files are created but only the first file name is prompted for. If this filename is "myplot.gnuplot", the second file will then be named "myplot.data". The actual graph can then be displayed using the command load "mygraph.gnuplot" at the gnuplot prompt.

mediaobject.caption: Examples of the two kinds of gnuplot graphs. The first one uses arrows of different colors to show changes in the expression levels. The second one show separate subgraphs for each gene.
